article:
__NOTOC__ This is a 'list of Jewish-American mobsters' and organized crime
figures, ranging from the late 19th century to the present day.

{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- valign="top"
! style="width:12%;"| Name style="width:5%;"|Portrait style="width:6%;"| Life
! style="width:6%;"| Years active style="width:20%;"| Notes style="width:2%;"|
! References
|-
|Hyman Abrams
| No image available style="text-align:center;"| style="text-
|align:center;"|1920sâ1960s
|Lieutenant of Boston Mobster Charles Solomon during Prohibition. Later financed
syndicate Las Vegas casinos with Meyer Lansky, Carl Cohen and Jack Entratter
during the 1950s and 60s.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Evsei Agron
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|d. 1985 style="text-
|align:center;"|1970sâ1980s
|Russian-born mobster who established and ran the Russian Mafia in Brighton
Beach, Brooklyn until his murder in 1985.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Israel "Ice pick Willie" Alderman
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1902-1970 style="text-
|align:center;"| From North Minneapolis; associate with David Berman (mobster)
|In Minneapolis and Las Vegas. 1965 Convicted in Denver Colorado of conspiring
|of using telephone lines to threaten death to a disbarred attorney; 1969
|reported under indictment for grand larceny. style="text-align:center;"| A
|Report on Chicago Crime {Chicago Crime Commission}" p.66 -
|Hyman Amberg
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1902â1926 style="text-
|align:center;"|1919â1926
|New York mobster and chief enforcer for his brothers Joseph and Louis "Pretty"
Amberg. Hyman and another convict committed suicide following an unsuccessful
escape attempt from Tombs Prison.
| style="text-align:center;"| Abramovitch, Ilana. Jews of
| Brooklyn. Hanover and London: University Press of New England, 2001. ISBN 978-1-58465-003-
| 4 Block, Alan A. East Side, West Side: Organizing Crime
| in New York, 1930â1950. New Brunswick, New Jersey: Transaction Books, 1983.
| ISBN 978-0-87855-931-2 -
|Joseph Amberg
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1892â1935 style="text-
|align:center;"|1919â1935
|New York mobster who led one of the top gangs in Brooklyn during the 1920s and
30s with brothers Hyman and Louis Amberg. Amberg and an associate, Morris
Kessler, were executed by Murder Inc. in his Brownsville auto garage.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Louis "Pretty" Amberg
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1897â1935 style="text-
|align:center;"|1919â1935
|He and brothers Hyman and Joseph Amberg led one of the top criminal gangs in
Brooklyn during the 1920s and 30s. The last surviving brother, he was murdered a
month after his brother Joseph by members of Murder Inc.
| style="text-align:center;"| Sifakis, Carl. The Mafia Encyclopedia. New York: Da Capo Press,
| 2005. ISBN 978-0-8160-5694-1 -
|Moses Annenberg
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1877â1942 style="text-
|align:center;"|1904â1936
|Newspaperman and organized crime figure. Hired and directed criminal gangs on
behalf of the Hearst Corporation during Chicago's "circulation wars" of
1910â1911, and later became owner of the National Racing Wire during the 1920s
and 30s. Later used his wealth to purchase The Philadelphia Inquirer and found
the Annenberg Foundation. Jailed for tax evasion in 1939.
| style="text-align:center;"| Fried, Albert. The Rise and Fall
| of the Jewish Gangster in America. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston, 1980.
| ISBN 978-0-231-09683-6 Newton, Michael. Mr. Mob: The
| Life and Crimes of Moe Dalitz. Jefferson, North Carolina: McFarland, 2009.
| ISBN 978-0-7864-3516-6 Johnson,
| Curt and R. Craig Sautter. The Wicked City: Chicago from Kenna to Capone. New
| York: Da Capo Press, 1998. (pg. 203-204) ISBN 978-0-306-80821-0 Woodiwiss, Michael. Organized Crime and American Power: A
| History. Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2001. ISBN 978-0-8020-8278-
| 7 Reppetto, Thomas A. American Mafia: A History of
| Its Rise to Power. New York: Henry Holt & Co., 2004. ISBN 978-0-8050-7798-
| 8 -
|Marat Balagula
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|b. 1943 style="text-
|align:center;"|1977â1986
|Associate of the Lucchese crime family during the 1970s and 80s. Succeeded
Evsei Agron as head of the Russian Mafia in 1985 but fled the country to avoid
criminal charges a year later. He was extradited back to the US in 1989 and
received a 18-year sentence in federal prison.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|David Berman
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1903â1957 style="text-
|align:center;"|1916â1957
|Associate member of the Genovese crime family who ran syndicate operations in
Iowa and Minnesota from the 1920s to the 40s. Involve in syndicate casinos in
Las Vegas during the 1940s and 50s, he and Moe Sedway took over The Flamingo
after Bugsy Siegel's murder in 1947.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Otto "Abbadabba" Berman
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1889â1935 style="text-
|align:center;"|1920sâ1930s
|Mob accountant and financial advisor for New York mobster Dutch Schultz.
| style="text-align:center;"| Cohen, Rich. Tough Jews: Fathers, Sons, and Gangster Dreams. New
| York: Simon and Schuster, 1998. ISBN 978-0-684-83115-2 -
|Abe Bernstein
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1892â1968 style="text-
|align:center;"|1910sâ1960s
|Detroit mobster and leader of The Purple Gang. After the end of Prohibition, he
ran syndicate gambling operations in Miami up until his death in 1968.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|William Morris Bioff
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1900â1955 style="text-
|align:center;"|1920sâ1930s
|Chicago labor racketeer who extorted millions of dollars from Hollywood studios
on behalf of the Chicago Outfit during the 1930s.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Charles Birger
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1881â1928 style="text-
|align:center;"|1919â1928
|Illinois bootlegger who feuded with the Shelton Brothers Gang throughout
Prohibition.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Alex "Shondor" Birns
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1907â1975 style="text-
|align:center;"|
|A major gangland figure in Cleveland throughout the 20th century. At one time
considered Public Enemy No. 1, he controlled the city's underworld until his
murder by Danny Greene in 1975.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Herbert Blitzstein
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1934â1997 style="text-
|align:center;"|
|Loanshark and bookmaker for the Chicago Outfit during the 1950s and 60s. He
was the top lieutenant of Anthony Spilotro when he and his crew were sent to
Las Vagas.
| style="text-align:center;"| Farrell, Ronald A. and Carole
| Case. The Black Book and the Mob: The Untold Story of the Control of Nevada's
| Casinos. Madison: University of Wisconsin Press, 1995. ISBN 978-0-299-14754-
| 9 -
|Ike Bloom
|
| style="text-align:center;"|1865â1930 style="text-align:center;"|
|An early organized crime figure in Chicago associated with "Big Jim" Colosimo.
Owned some of the city's most popular nightclubs, such as Midnight Forlics and
Kreiberg's, during Prohibition.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Isadore "Kid Cann" Blumenfeld
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1900â1981 style="text-
|align:center;"|1900sâ1980s
|Minneapolis mobster who ran the city's underworld from the 1920s until his
conviction for violating the Mann Act in 1957. Later retired to Miami Beach
where he and Meyer Lansky operated a real estate empire and were involved in
syndicate operations in Miami and Havana up until his death in 1981.
| style="text-align:center;"| Rockaway, Robert A. But He Was Good to His Mother: The Lives
| and Crimes of Jewish Gangsters. Jerusalem: Gefen Publishing House, 1993. ISBN
| 978-965-229-092-2 -
|Louis "Lepke" Buchalter
|
| style="text-align:center;"|1897â1944 style="text-align:center;"|1910sâ1940s
|New York labor racketeer who dominated the Lower East Side with Jacob Shapiro
during the 1920s and 30s. Later headed Murder Inc. and was eventually sent to
the electric chair at Sing Sing for his role in the organization. He is the only
major mobster to be executed by the state.
| style="text-align:center;"| Rubin, Rachel. Jewish Gangsters of Modern
| Literature. Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 2000. ISBN 978-0-252-02539-
| 6 Willis, Clint. Wise Guys: Stories of Mobsters from
| Jersey to Vegas. New York: Thunder's Mouth Press, 2003. ISBN 978-1-56025-498-
| 0 -
|Mickey Cohen
|
| style="text-align:center;"|1914â1976 style="text-align:center;"|1923â1961
|Major underworld figure in Los Angeles during the 1930s and 40s. Later helped
Bugsy Siegel set up The Flamingo in Las Vegas and ran its sports book operation.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Louis Cohen
|
| style="text-align:center;"|1904â1939 style="text-align:center;"|1910sâ1930s
|New York mobster who killed Nathan Kaplan on behalf of rival labor racketeers
Jacob Orgen and Louis Buchalter in 1923.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Moe Dalitz
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1899â1989 style="text-
|align:center;"|1920sâ1960s
|Leader of the Mayfield Road Gang during Prohibition. He was later involved the
development of syndicate gaming in Las Vegas during the 1940s and 50s.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Stanley Diamond
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1922â1991 style="text-
|align:center;"|1960sâ1970s
|Associate member of the Lucchese crime family associated with Henry Hill and
Jimmy Burke during the 1970s.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Monk Eastman
|
| style="text-align:center;"|1873â1920 style="text-align:center;"|1898â1920
|Founder of the Eastman Gang, one of the last of New York's major street gangs,
and dominated the city's underworld around the start of the 20th century.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Monya Elson
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|b. 1951 style="text-
|align:center;"|1970sâ1990s
|Russian-born mobster who feuded with Boris Nayfeld over control of Brighton
Beach, Brooklyn during the 1990s. One of Ukrainian mobster Semion Mogilevich's
closest associates, he at one time controlled a criminal empire stretching from
Russia to New York and Los Angeles.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Maxie Eisen
| No image available style="text-align:center;"| style="text-
|align:center;"|1910sâ1920s
|Chicago labor racketeer allied with Dion O'Banion and the North Side Gang, and
later for the Joe Saltis-Frank McErlane Gang during the 1920s.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|John Factor
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1892â1984 style="text-
|align:center;"|1920sâ1960s
|British-born Chicago gangster and con artist associated with the Chicago
Outfit whose staged 1933 kidnapping resulted in the wrongful conviction of
Roger Touhy. He later became a prominent businessman and casino owner in Las
Vegas 1950s and 60s.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Ludwig "Tarzan" Fainberg
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|b. 1958 style="text-
|align:center;"|1980â1999
|Ukrainian-born New York mobster associated with the Russian Mafia in Brighton
Beach, Brooklyn and South Florida during the 1990s. He was convicted on
Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act charges for his involvement
in arraigning the sale a Russian submarine to a group of Colombian drug
dealers in 1999.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Benjamin "Dopey Benny" Fein
|
| style="text-align:center;"|1889â1977? style="text-align:center;"|1900â1941
|New York mobster who dominated labor racketeering with Joseph Rosenzweig in the
Lower East Side during the 1910s.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Irving Feinstein
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1910â1939 style="text-
|align:center;"|1930s
|New York mobster involved in illegal gambling and labor racketeering with Louis
"Lepke" Buchalter during the 1930s.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Abraham Friedman
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1897â1939 style="text-
|align:center;"|1920sâ1930s
|New York mobster and enforcer for labor racketeer Nathan Kaplan, and later
Louis Buchalter and Jacob Shapiro during the 1920s and 30s.

|Isadore Friedman
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|d. 1939 style="text-

| style="text-align:center;"| -

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1905â1941 style="text-

| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Waxey Gordon
|
| style="text-align:center;"|1889â1952 style="text-align:center;"|1900sâ1950s
|New York mobster who oversaw bootlegging operations for Arnold Rothstein during
Prohibition. He was eventually imprisoned for tax evasion in 1933 and, again in

|Gus Greenbaum
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1894â1958 style="text-

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|d. 1939 style="text-

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1883â1933 style="text-

| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Jake "Greasy Thumb" Guzik
| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1886â1956 style="text-

|
| style="text-align:center;"|1889â1914 style="text-align:center;"|1900sâ1910s

| style="text-align:center;"| - "Kid

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1893â1962 style="text-

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1952â1975 style="text-

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1888-? style="text-

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1908â1971 style="text-

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|d. 1941 style="text-

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|fl. 1933â1939

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1919â1979 style="text-

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|fl. 1959â1974

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1898â1935 style="text-

|
| style="text-align:center;"|1902â1983 style="text-align:center;"|1910sâ1970s

|
| style="text-align:center;"|1903â1972 style="text-align:center;"|1920sâ1930s

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1899â1994 style="text-

| No image available style="text-align:center;"| style="text-

||
| style="text-align:center;"|1901â1927 style="text-align:center;"|1900sâ1920s

| No image available style="text-align:center;"| style="text-

the largest wholesale liquor distributorship in NJ.

|

|

|Longtime associate of Meyer Lansky, he was a member of the Bug and Meyer Mob

|

| No image available style="text-align:center;"|1898â1997 style="text-
|align:center;"|1920sâ1990s
|Ran one of the largest bookmaking operations in Boston during the 1950s. At the

|

|
| style="text-align:center;"|1894â1952 style="text-align:center;"|1920sâ1950s

| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Irving, Meyer and William Shapiro
|
| style="text-align:center;"|1904â1931 (Irving) 1908â1931
| (Meyer) 1911â1934 (William) style="text-align:center;"|1920sâ1930s
|Rivals of Louis Buchalter and Jacob Shapiro during the late 1920s and 1930s.
Irving and Meyer Shapiro were killed after initiating a gang war with
Buchalter and Shapiro in 1931. William Shapiro was eventually murdered by
Murder Inc. in 1934.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Jacob "Gurrah" Shapiro
||
| style="text-align:center;"|1899â1947 style="text-align:center;"|1910sâ1940s
|He and Louis Buchalter controlled industrial labor racketeering in New York
during the 1920s and 30s. Shapiro also helped establish Murder Incorporated.
Died in prison in 1947.
| style="text-align:center;"| -
|Benjamin "Bugsy" Siegel
|
| style="text-align:center;"|1906â1947 style="text-align:center;"|1910sâ1940s
|New York mobster associated with Meyer Lansky, Frank Costello and Charles
"Lucky" Luciano during Prohibition. Credited for the creation of syndicate
casinos in Las Vegas during the 1940s.

|He and Irish gangster Dan Carroll controlled bootlegging, narcotics and illegal
gambling in Boston during Prohibition. Killed at the Cotton Club by rival
mobsters in 1933.

|
| style="text-align:center;"|d. 1908 style="text-align:center;"|1890sâ1900s

|
